titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Sunday. Rain, the greater part of the day. In the morning I heard a Stranger at the Presbyterian Church, from Matthew 5.14. [“]Ye are the light of the world. A city that is set on a hill cannot be hid. 15. Neither do men light a candle, and put it under a bushel; but on a candlestick; and it giveth light to all that are in the House. 16. Let your Light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in Heaven.”— No afternoon service at that Church— At St. John’s Church at 5. P.M. heard Mr. M’Callum read prayers for the first Sunday after Trinity, and preach from John 4:24. “God is a Spirit, and they that worship him, must worship him in Spirit and in truth.” The remainder of the day was consumed in writing an answer to the Blue Book received from Christopher Hughes— My wife, who was quite unwell all day yesterday and last Night, was this day confined to her bed— Our house is a hospital— My Son and his wife always in a precarious state of health, and subject to sudden and violent attacks— Their two children sickly, and when well too delicate to bear the slightest exposure— Mrs Good, the Nurse of the children, having a daughter subject to convulsion fits, and the Servants often sick— My own health, formerly so robust, having become so exceedingly variable. I am bound to consider these as visitations of Providence, perhaps intended to wean me from a world, where I have had my share of blessing and enjoyment, and from which I must very shortly be withdrawn— Public Affairs, inauspicious as their movements are afford me rather relief and relaxation from these heavier domestic and personal afflictions— As in paroxysms of disease we sometimes obtain partial and momentary relief by turning over from one side to the other. I find it difficult to keep up the record of my life as it is passing away. Wilson my new Coachman took a bad cold yesterday by exposure to the rain. He has taken the place of John Kirk, who some weeks since very suddenly left this City and went to Boston, and then to Quincy, where his wife was left last Winter to take care of our house. He now works in the Garden there. Wilson’s wife has taken the place of Margaret as attendant upon Mrs. Adams, and more than supplies it, being an excellent Nurse.
2. V:30. Monday.

Sonnet to Mrs Lay.— I called at the Secretary of State’s Office, and had a conversation with Mr M’Lane concerning the claims of L. Kervand, the Restaurateur upon Baron Stackelberg, late Swedish Chargé d’Affaires, and Mr Krehmer, Secretary of the Russian Legation— Mr M’Lane told me that he would again instruct Mr Hughes to claim payment of Baron Stackelberg’s debts, one of which was for money furnished him by this Government, upon his Bill of exchange, when I was President. He said Hughes had been once instructed to claim the payment of Stackelberg’s debts, and had applied without success. He said further that if Kervand would make his claim against Krehmer, in writing he would instruct Mr Dickerson, who is going out Minister to Russia to demand payment of it there. He added that there were much heavier demands against Baron Krudener, the Russian Minister, and against Mr Torlade d’Azambuja the Miguelite Portuguese Chargé d’Affaires. At the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, Andrew Stevenson the Speaker addressed the House, and resigned his Office; stating that he had this day addressed a Letter to the Executive of Virginia, resigning his seat as a member of the House— He then took leave of the House in a Speech of 15 minutes full of good principles and good feeling, in elegant language, very handsomely delivered— The House immediately proceeded to ballot for Speaker— There were ten ballots taken, at the last of which John Bell of Tennessee was chosen by 114 of 215 votes— He was conducted by me, and Richard M. Johnson to the Chair, whence he made a short address to the House, and took the Oath to support the Constitution of the United States administered by Lewis Williams of North-Carolina the person who has been longest in con
tinuance a member of the House; immediately after which the House adjourned. The competitors for the Chair, were Wilde and Wayne of Georgia, Polk of Tennessee, and Sutherland of Pennsylvania— William A. Bradley was this day elected Mayor of the City— John was absent all day at the City Election— Lord Powerscourt and Mr Parnell, left the City. Evening visit from General Macomb, and Mr De Peyster of New-York.
3. V:15. Tuesday.

Mark Stokes brought me a Letter to John M’Morine of Elizabeth City—North-Carolina—son of one of the Executors of the Will of his uncle, from which he claims an Estate—which Letter I undertook to forward for him— At the House, several of the Members of the delegation from the recent Pennsylvania Convention were introduced to me, and also Mr Brown of New-Orleans, who asked to see me at home, upon some claim of that city which he wished to explain to me— I agreed to see him to-morow morning at 9.— After the reading of the Journal, Reports were received from the standing Committees, and among them was a Bill by Stoddert from the Committee on the District of Columbia, to prohibit the District City Corporations from issuing Notes under ten dollars, from and after the year 1839. and requiring them within the five years to withdraw the notes of the same denomination which they have now in circulation— Chinn shewed me the Bill yesterday— I asked the unanimous consent of the House to devote this day to receiving Memorials and Petitions, instead of yesterday, the regular Petition day; but which was consumed in the election of a Speaker. Objection was made. Denny moved the suspension of the Rule, but the House refused. The contested Kentucky Election was resumed, and a question arose upon two votes, struck out by the Committee of Elections, because there was Evidence, that the voters were not known— A stubborn debate arose, in which I took a part, and which continued till the adjournment of the House, without taking the question.
4. V. Wednesday.
My wife was very suddenly seized, with extreme violence with a fainting fit, in bed, from which she fell out, and which was followed by severe cramps and great sickness.

Mr Brown from New-Orleans came, and explained to me the agreement upon which the judiciary Committee had reported the Bill, N. 420 securing to the city of New-Orleans the property of certain Land, bordering upon the river Mississippi, upon condition of the cession by the City to the United States of their claim to a square upon which the Custom-House is built— They are extremely anxious that the Bill should pass at the present Session of Congress, and I promised every assistance that it may be in my power to give for that purpose. I found the House in Session— Edward Everett from the joint Committee on the Library, reported a joint Resolution for distributing the copies of the Diplomatic Correspondence of the United States from the Peace of 1783 to the 4th. of March 1789. recently published: it was twice read; and passed to be engrossed, by yeas and nays 110 to 57. The Kentucky Election was then resumed, and after a renewed debate the amendment to restore to Letcher the two votes of persons not known was rejected by yeas and nays 93 to 115— Two other questions upon individual names were successively taken, in which the amendment was adopted 104 to 100 upon one parcel, and rejected 89 to 116 upon the other. Patrick H. Pope then proposed a Resolution, that sundry votes for Moore, disallowed by the Committee should be restored to him—and that votes allowed for Letcher, be struck out as minors or Non-Residents, upon which he made a Speech of two hours— Banks rose to reply; but as it was past four O’Clock moved an adjournment which was carried by yeas and nays 104 to 89.— Thunder Showers— I dined with Mr Webster upon Salmon, sent him from New-York— Silsbee, Bell of New Hampshire
Sprague of Maine, Southard of New-Hampshire, Waggaman of Louisiana, Edward Everett, Commodore Chauncey, and Letcher were there. Waggaman and Southard, asked my opinion what they should do upon the nomination of Stevenson as Minister to Great Britain— I advised them earnestly to vote for the confirmation of his appointment— On returning home I found Dr Huntt at our house, and my wife better than in the morning.
5. V. Thursday.

Slept in the small front chamber— My wife, better, but still confined to her bed, very ill.— At the House, Sherman Page of New-York asked me for a Letter of introduction to John Cuthbert, Consul of the United States at Hamburg for Colonel Samuel Starkweather of Otsego in the State of New-York, which I gave him— This day had been specially assigned for Bills relating to the Territories— The Resolution for distributing the volumes of the Supplementary Diplomatic Correspondence from 1783 to 1789 was taken up by unanimous consent and passed— Some other Reports from Committees were received—and then the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, James M. Wayne in the Chair, upon Bills relating to the Territories— Sundry Bills passed through the Committee, with or without Amendments, and with occasional debate— A Bill relating to the tracing of the boundary line between the State of Georgia, and the Territory of Florida, was debated, by Thomas F. Foster and George R. Gilmer of Georgia for the State, and Joseph M. White the Delegate, for the Territory. An amendment to the Bill offered by Foster was rejected. Afterwards a Bill for selling the lead mine Lands was much and very variously discussed. Several Bills also went through the Committee without Amendment; and they were all reported to the House together. An attempt was made to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up a territorial Bill, in that Committee, but it failed— The Bills reported to the House passed to be engrossed, with several exceptions— Some of the amendments adopted in Committee were rejected by the House— Adjourned about 5— I walked home— After dinner I planted in the garden several Strawberries for seed. Coll. and Mrs Aspinwall were here this Evening— They arrived with their family at Boston last August, and have been travelling in various parts of the Country since that time. Coll Aspinwall spoke to me, in behalf of Petty Vaughan, and left with me a Letter from him.

6. V:30. Friday.— Morning absorbed in finishing a Letter to Benjamin F. Hallett— At the House this day and to-morrow had been assigned specially for the consideration of Bills, reported by the Committee on the District of Columbia. A motion was made by Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, to suspend the Rule fixing this day for the District business, and to take up the Appropriation Bills, but it failed— A Bill was received from the Senate N 129. “to settle and establish the Northern boundary line of the State of Ohio.”— The House went into Committee of the whole George M. Briggs in the Chair, and took up several Bills in Succession. One or two Bills passed with little opposition— Then came the Bill for incorporating the Association for erecting in the City of Washington a monument, in honour of him— A long debate arose first on the 8th. Section of the Bill, and then upon the Bill itself— I spoke against the motion to strike out the Section, and it kindled a doubly fierce opposition to the Bill— Burges and Pearce of Rhode-Island, disagreeing upon every thing else, united in this opposition joined by Hardin of Kentucky and Moore of Virginia— In the hottest of the debate, it was discovered that the Bill had not been referred to the Committee— The next Bill taken up was for an annual appropriation of 60,000 dollars for three years, to pay the interest on the Canal debt of this City— It was first recommended by a Speech from John T. Stoddert, answered by a vehement assault upon it from Hardin. To this Mercer replied with great and spontaneous eloquence— Hardin rejoined, and the debate was pursued, by Mann of New-York, Chinn, Wardwell, Stewart and M’Kennan— About 5 O’Clock, Parker of New-Jersey insisted upon giving his reasons for his vote against the Bill, and as he was known to be long-winded
the Committee rose and the House adjourned. I walked home— Weather very warm I missed attending the horticultural exhibition, at the City Hall, yesterday and this day. My wife is convalescent— My Son John’s child Mary-Louisa was quite ill, late this Evening.
7. V:30. Saturday.

An old purblind Sailor named Cornelius Butler came and told me that he was a native of Massachusetts, and had been many years a Carpenter in the naval Service of the United States, and as late as last Summer in the Navy-Yard at Charlestown; but he is now making his way, poor, pennyless and almost famished to claim a pension— I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy— I called at the Department of State, and Mr M’Lane the Secretary being absent, I left with Asbury Dickins the chief Clerk a Letter fromThayer a Seaman, at Flushing, enlisted in the service of the King of Holland, and desiring to obtain his discharge; and also a Letter from his father, and his Grandfather Vinson at Weymouth— Mr Dickins promised me an answer— At the House, After some competition to fix upon the business to be taken up for the first hour, my Resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury for information concerning the deposit Banks, was preferred, and debated till the expiration of the hour— Polk, moved an amendment with the intention of defeating the Resolution; and Beaty moved an amendment to Polk’s amendment, chiefly to teaze him. At Noon the business of the District of Columbia was taken up as the special order of the day, and the House went into Committee of the whole, George M. Briggs in the Chair— The Bill appropriating sixty thousand dollars a year for three years to pay the interest on the Washington City debt was resumed and after further debate, Parker moved to strike out the enacting clause— Motion rejected— The Bill, and sundry others, among which was the Bill prohibiting the District City Corporations, from issuing notes under the denomination of ten dollars, were reported to the House—some with and some without amendments— The House then went again into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, H. Hubbard in the Chair; upon two other Bills—one for the construction of a Bridge over the Potowmac; the other, of appropriations for the public buildings. After much skirmishing debate, they were both reported to the House with Amendments. I offered an Amendment appropriating one thousand dollars, for a monument to be erected over the remains of Major General Jacob Brown, which was adopted without opposition. H. Hubbard spoke to me, about his Son, in trouble at Cambridge. Adjourned at 1/2 past 5. My Son dined with the horticultural Society— And Mr Frye who was here in the Evening— Mrs Frye and Mrs. Smith had also been here.

8. V:30: Sunday. It is impossible for me to answer a tenth part of the Letters that I receive; and my files of Letters run into confusion— I gave much of this day to assorting them— In the morning at the Presbyterian Church, Mr Smith was in the Pulpit, but a Stranger preached from Isaiah 53.5. [“]But he was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities.”— A thoroughgoing Calvinistic Discourse— I never hear a Calvinistic Sermon, earnestly preached without continual self enquiry, whether the preacher can possibly believe what he says? I read also a high toned Calvinistic Sermon upon the mediatorial character of Christ; by Mr Daniel Baker, who gave it to me upon his recent visit to this City— He intended to put his whole strength into it, and considers it as his masterpiece— In the afternoon at St. John’s Church the service was performed for the second Sunday after Trinity, followed by a short Sermon— In the Evening, I wrote to Mr John W. Foster, a printer at Portsmouth, New-Hampshire, to whom I returned a subscription paper received from him nearly two months since, for a Volume of posthumous Sermons, by Dr Nathan Parker of that place— The Prospectus for the publication speaks of him, as a very eminent divine; but I think I had never heard of him before I received this Subscription-paper— I shall take a copy of his Sermons.

9. V. Monday.— I attended at the War Department, upon applications from Leonard Howe, with enclosure from his Son Samuel Barnett Howe of 30. April last, soliciting admission as a Cadet at West Point—from Jacob H. Loud 26. May 1834. for George Torrey—for bounty Lands—and Asa Lapham’s pension papers, from Marshfield— Also from Silas Paine junr 10. May 1834—for Levi Hayden and his Widow Hannah Hayden— The Secretary of War is, and has been several days ill; and was not at the Office— I saw the Chief Clerk, and left the papers with him, and enquiries with the Commissioner of Pensions—James L. Edwards for Answer. At the House, the Speaker announced the order of the day to be a Memorial, from Pennsylvania, upon which Mr Barnitz had the floor. Miller of Pennsylvania asked the consent of the House to take up my Resolution, calling for information respecting the depositary Banks; but objection was made, and Miller did not move the suspension of the Rule. Barnitz made his Speech on the Pennsylvania Memorial, which then was at Polk’s motion, laid on the table— Polk moved also to suspend the Rules to take up the Appropriation Bills—Yeas and Nays 113 to 64, not two thirds— Wise’s Resolutions against the President’s Protest, engrafted upon a Bank and deposite Memorial from Gloucester County, Virginia, were urged by an eloquent and tedious Speech of Wise— He was followed by Peyton of Tennessee with a glorification Speech, and his Resolutions against the Senate as Amendments to those of Wise.— Miller of Pennsylvania moved to lay both sets of Resolutions on the Table— Wise moved a call of the House, which was ordered. 188 members answered to their names and excuses were received from 16—nearly 40 members were not to be found— Further proceedings on the Call were suspended at the motion of Joel K. Mann of Pennsylvania 117 to 63.— Beardsley moved to adjourn—rejected by yeas and nays 78 to 115— Both sets of Resolutions were laid on the table 105 to 97— Adjourned. I went into the Senate— Post-Office Reports, Majority and Minority, read— Discussion about printing an extra number of copies. Poindexter had introduced a Bill, for Congress to meet on the second Monday of November, next— Opposed by Clay, Calhoun and Webster, and laid on the Table— The Senate agreed to the Resolution from the House to adjourn on the 30th of this Month— Fahrenheit 92.
10. V. Tuesday.

A restless and almost sleepless night, from the heat of the weather, with a flat and dead calm, and Fahrenheit above 80— Mr Choate called upon me with a Gentleman by the name of Taylor— Conversation engaged me to talk till I wasted their time and mine— I found the House in Session. Reports were received from standing Committees— Several attempts were made to suspend the Rules, that Resolutions might be offered, and Memorials received; but they all failed— Parker from the Committee of Naval Affairs, reported a Bill N. 522 to establish rations for the Navy—read twice and committed to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union— C. F. Mercer moved a rule to be added to the standing Rules of the House—giving every member entitled to the floor, to move that any pending debate shall cease—and if seconded by a majority of the House, the question upon the pending motion shall be taken without further debate— Mercer’s motion lies over, one day— The Kentucky contested election was taken up, and Patrick H. Pope modified his Amendment offered last Friday. It appeared that some of the votes, that he wished to have stricken from Letchers poll had already been deducted from it. There remained from 30 to 40 votes, which he moved by five Resolutions to have struck off from Letcher’s poll, as minors, or not citizens, or as having been counted for him by mistake, and to be added to the poll of Moore. The yeas and nays were taken seven times with various results, on petty varieties of testimony— I voted in every instance against striking out, approving on this point the principle adopted by the Committee of Elections, to admit no such postliminary testimony to invalidate votes, received on either side— I spoke also against the reversal of this principle, but without effect— The house did reverse it, and struck out successively several votes
from Letcher’s poll; refusing to strike out others— Three calls were made for the Previous question; the first and second time falling short of a second— The third time, the motion was made by Lytle immediately after the House had struck out from Letcher’s Poll, every vote they could, on evidence that the voters were minors, and to prevent the application of the same principle to Moore’s poll. On the vote taken by Tellers there were then 105 for and 96 against seconding the motion— When my name was called, I asked what the effect of the previous question would be, and stated it amidst stunning cries of order, and gentle remonstrances of the new Speaker (Bell) against discussion; but I persisted till he answered my question— The main question would have been ay or no upon the Resolution reported by the Committee of Elections, that Thomas P. Moore was entitled to the Seat, and the effect of the Previous Question would have been to annul, all the decisions on the House, restoring to Letcher the votes unjustly struck from his Poll by the Committee— The restoration of these votes, gave Letcher the legal majority, and the previous question would not only have taken it from him again, but brought the whole party machinery to bear on the naked declaration that Moore was entitled to the Seat— Marshall moved a call of the House which was carried 119 to 85—220 Members answered to their names, and excuses were received from 7— Even the suspension of further proceedings upon the call, moved by Mann was contested by yeas and nays 130 to 84— Hardin moved an adjournment—rejected 56 to 158— Marshall called for the reading of the portion of the report of the Committee of Elections, which contains a statement of the votes.— The Speaker decided this to be out of order, as equivalent to debate— Marshall appealed from the decision of the Speaker which was confirmed by the House— Mercer, moved a reconsideration of the vote striking out Letcher’s minors; for which he had voted, in the confidence that the same principle would be applied to Moore’s poll; which was now to be evaded— The Speaker decided that this was not in order; from which Mercer appealed, but after debate, withdrew the appeal— The vote upon the Previous Question was that the main Question should not now be put. 108 to 112. and the House at 1/2 past eight in the evening adjourned— I took George W. Lay home— Heat insupportable— I stood great part of the day at one of the open windows of the Hall—

11. IV:15. Wednesday.— Restless night again but with a more temperate atmosphere than the night before— This morning at the House— The Resolution offered on the 10th. of April, by Lucius Lyon, the delegate from the Territory of Michigan, for information relative to the Latitude and Longitude of several places in the vicinity of the Northern boundary of the States of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois was adopted— The Bill from the Senate. N. 129. to settle and establish the Northern boundary line of the State of Ohio, was twice read, and William Allen of Ohio moved to postpone the consideration of it till to morrow week, and made the special order for that day.— Lyon the Delegate from Michigan, moved that it should be referred to the Committee on the Judiciary— Allen made a very vehement Speech—Lyon’s reply was arrested by the expiration of the hour— The Kentucky Election case was resumed; further questions were taken upon striking out 3 or 4 more minors from the poll of R. P. Letcher— Then Marshall moved to strike off a number of votes from the poll of Moore then followed a long loose debate upon a succession of names; on each of which the question was taken of striking it off, and carried pro and con— After much nibbling at votes on both sides, and yeas and nays repeatedly taken, M’Kay moved to Commit the whole Report of the Committee of Elections and all the Amendments adopted and under Consideration to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, with Instructions to report a Resolution, declaring the Election in the 5th. Congressional District of Kentucky void for uncertainty and irregularity, and that neither Thomas P. Moore, nor Robert P. Letcher was entitled to a seat in the House— There was another Resolution to allow both Letcher and Moore pay as members during their attendance, which on objection being made he withdrew— Then came a Call of the House
moved by Ben. Hardin, upon which 221 members answered to their names, and excuses were received from 7— Then a warm debate, upon which M’Kay modified his Resolution, which was finally carried by yeas and nays 113 to 109. The majority consisted of M’Kay himself and Wise of Virginia, men whose moral principle consists in taking the stand half-way between right and wrong— A great effort was made to go into the Committee of the whole immediately; but it was near eight in the Evening, and at a second trial the House adjourned— Heath and Turner voted for M’Kay’s Resolution, and Hard was absent— Heath promised to move a reconsideration of the vote— I sent a notification to the members of the Committee of Manufactures to meet at ten O’Clock to-morrow Morning.

12. V. Thursday. I took my Son Johns two children with me to the Capitol and shewed them the Hall of the House of Representatives, and the Rotunda with its Pictures— At ten O’Clock only four members of the Committee of Manufactures met—Philemon Dickerson, William M’Comas, Gayton P. Osgood and myself— The only paper referred to the Committee which we took up, was a petition from Peter Bastres, asking a national reward for having discovered the Anthracite Coal-mines in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania— It was the unanimous opinion of the members present of the Committee to report against it— I said I should probably call only one more Meeting of the Committee, at the close of the Session— At the House I offered a Resolution for printing 10000 copies of the Reports to the Senate on the Post-Office, for the use of the House— I asked unanimous consent to consider it; but objection was made, and I desisted— Several attempts were made to suspend the rule but failed— There was some discussion upon a Bill from the Senate concerning the boundary between the State of Ohio and the Territory of Michigan— Lyons motion to refer it to the Committee on the judiciary was withdrawn— Vance of Ohio, moved its reference to a select Committee of 23. one from each State, and excepting Ohio— This was debated until the expiration of the hour, and the Kentucky Election came up— Heath did not move the re-consideration of the yesterday’s reference, as he had promised he would— M’Kim had been with him and threatened that if he did, the administration party would defeat the Baltimore Rail-road Bill— The House went into Committee of the whole, pro forma. H. Hubbard in the Chair, and reported M’Kay’s Resolution, as instructed, in this form. “Resolved, that there be a new Election, for a member of this House, from the fifth Congressional district, in Kentucky, it being impracticable for the House to determine, with any certainty who is the rightful Representative of said district.”— Clayton moved to amend the Resolution, by declaring Letcher entitled to the Seat— There was a call of the House at the motion of Moore of Virginia, 224 members answered to their names, and excuses were received from 7.— Further proceedings in the call were dispensed with, at the motion of Mann of New-York. 148 to 65— On Clayton’s motion the vote was 112 to 114— I moved to strike out the words declaring it impracticable for the house to determine who was the rightful Representative of the district;—but this motion was rejected— Clayton moved a preamble stating the facts proving Letcher to be elected; which he withdrew at the request of Hardin, but it was renewed by Garland, and rejected 72 to 136— The Resolution as reported by the Committee of the whole was then carried 114 to 103— The Bill for the relief of Edmund Brooke followed, authorizing him to bring two Slaves into the District— I moved it should be postponed, to the first Monday in December— Wardwell moved to lay it on the Table—rejected 69 to 95.— Clay moved the previous question; which was carried, and the Bill passed—106 to 47. 70 members avoiding to vote— A Bill from the Senate to revive an act granting pre-emption rights to settlers on the public Lands, was read a third time, and while under debate the House adjourned— I dined with H. Binney, Harmar Denny, John G. Watmough, and the Mess lodging at Mrs Blake’s— We dined late, and it was past eleven O’Clock before I left the Table— C. F. Mercer, who was of the party came away, and walked most of the way home with me— The decision of the House in the case of the contested election, was the triumph of conscience over party, and of party over justice.

13. V:15. Friday.— At the Meeting of the House; prayer by Mr Stockton, and the Journal read, my Resolution, calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury for information respecting the depository Banks was taken up— Mr Beatty withdrew his proposed amendment to the Amendment moved by Polk to my Resolution— Beatty’s amendment was to enquire whether the President, and the Heads of the Departments kept their private Accounts with the United States Branch Bank. Polk’s amendment was to tack to my enquiry another and more extensive one concerning the President and Directors of the United States Bank— I called upon him in fairness to withdraw the amendment, obviously a mere indirect way of defeating the proposition— Polk refused to withdraw his amendment, and made a speech against the Bank— Wayne then began a speech both against Polk’s Amendment, and against my Resolution— His Speech was interrupted by the expiration of the hour— The Bill from the Senate to settle and establish the Northern Boundary of the State of Ohio, came up— W. Allen’s motion to postpone the consideration of it till next Thursday was rejected, and the Bill was referred to a Select Committee of seven members Then the two joint-Resolutions from the Senate, one declaring the reasons of the Secretary of the Treasury, for the removal of the deposits unsatisfactory, and the other directing the public funds to be deposited in the Bank of the United States and its branches, from and after the first of July next, were successively taken up, and at Polk’s motion laid on the table— Crockett moved a Call of the House—211 members answered to their names, and excuses were received from 7. Proceedings on the Call were then suspended at the motion of Joseph B. Anthony— The Resolution disapproving the removal of the deposits was laid on the Table 114 to 101. The resolution directing their restoration to the United States Bank 118 to 98— Next came a Bill reviving an act to secure a right of pre-emption to Settlers (Squatters) on the public Lands: opposed by Vinton of Ohio, who moved to strike out the enacting clause— It raised a Hornet’s nest from all the new States, and was finally put down, by a call for the Previous Question moved by Speight and carried— The Bill was passed 124 to 53— Then after an unsuccessful motion to adjourn the Indian Annuity Appropriation Bill was debated on the Amendments from the Committee of the whole, and was ordered to be engrossed for a third reading. I objected again to the amendment appropriating the 112000 dollars belonging to the Seneca Indians, but Mr Binney who agreed with me in the principle offered a proviso, reserving the Indian right, and the House, only 121 members present, not only agreed to the amendment, but refused the yeas and nays which I asked— The Bill passed and the House at 1/2 past 6 adjourned— I walked home, praying for restraining grace, the controul of my own Passions, Patience, Humility and Resignation to the Will of Heaven.

14. V. Saturday— At the House immediately after the reading of the Journal, Isaac M’Kim asked the consent of the House to offer a Resolution for the appointment of a Select Committee to enquire into and report upon the expediency of authorising the Secretary of the Treasury to issue fifteen Millions of Dollars of Treasury Notes, to be loaned by Commissioners to individual citizens, upon interest on good security, to be repaid in 1836— Objection was made to receiving the Resolution, and on M’Kims moving to suspend the Rule, there was found to be no Quorum— Archer from the Committee on foreign Affairs reported a Bill to carry into effect the Convention with Spain. On motion of Lucius Lyon, Delegate from the Territory of Michigan, the Clerk of the House, was directed to cause to be prepared, and printed as early as practicable, a correct map of the Northern boundary line of the State of Ohio; as surveyed, marked and designated, under the act of Congress of the 20th. of May 1812. together with so much of the Southern portion of the Territory of Michigan as may be necessary to fully understand the question of boundary now existing between Ohio and Michigan— The House by unanimous consent, on the motion of Polk went into Committee of the whole upon the state of the Union, upon several Appropriation Bills— The Indian annuity Appropriation Bill, and one other
having previously been read the third time and passed— The fortification Bill, a Bill for the re-appropriation of an unexpended balance for payment of Georgia Militia claims in 1792–3–4 and a Bill making additional appropriations for the armoury at Harper’s ferry for the year 1834 were carried through the Committee under the charge of Polk—the last two were reported to the House without amendment, passed to a third reading and passed— The Light House Bill in the care of Sutherland and the West Point Military Academy Appropriation Bill, under the protection of H. Binney, were carried with sundry slight amendments, and little debate, till Dickinson of Tennessee moved to strike out the enacting clause of the Military Academy Appropriation Bill, and made a patriotic Speech— Answered with great animation and persevering fluency by Ward of New-York— The debate was continued by Hawes of Kentucky, Smith of Maine, Ewing of Indiana, and others, but all their amendments were rejected, and the Bill, together, with gold and silver coin Bill, and the foreign gold coin Bill was reported to the House, which then adjourned soon after four. I spoke to Mr Bell, the Speaker, on his omission to call up my Resolution of enquiry, concerning the Banks, but he said he thought he had been right— He had suffered Polk to move and carry the suspension of the Rules, without giving notice that my Resolution was the unfinished business of yesterday, and as such had the preference of all other subjects— I dined with Mr Gorham, and Mr Baylies at Fuller’s Hotel. Governor Lincoln, Edward Everett, Choate and Briggs, Evans of Maine, Ashley of Missouri, and George C. Washington were the company.

15. V. Sunday. At the Presbyterian Church, morning Service— Mr Newell, a Minister from the Board of Missions, preached from Mark 16.15. “And he said unto them, go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature.” There was no collection taken up for the Missions, but notice was given by Mr Smith, that Mr Newell would in the course of the week call upon individuals of the Church for contributions, and Mr Newell said that all those upon whom he had called had contributed very liberally. Mr Wardwell of New-York was in my pew, and John Cramer the Successor of John W. Taylor in the next.— Mr Smith gave notice, that the afternoon Service would henceforth commence at 5 O’Clock— That is now the hour of Evening prayer at St. John’s Church— There I attended but it was a rainy Evening. Mr Hawley read Prayers for the third Sunday after Trinity, but there were no Singers to make melody in their Hearts with the Psalm and Hymn that he gave out, and I was the only person present who read the responses, and alternate verses for the Psalms— Without going into the Pulpit Mr Hawley gave a word of exhortation not exceeding five minutes in length, from 2. Corinthians 5.1. “For we know that if the earthly House of this Tabernacle were dissolved, we have a building of God, an house not made with hands, eternal in the Heavens”— A text which out not to be treated with five minutes of superficial extemporaneous discourse. I examined my files of Letters on private business, for application at the War Department to-morrow.— Samuel Sampson, The Letter of Application to me in his behalf— Constant Fobes Oakman—His Petition to Congress with a blank Declaration from the War Department. James Macauley—Letter, Frankfort, New-York 24. May 1834— Pension of Joseph French. Herkimer County, New-York. Anthony Collamore, Pembroke 9. Feby 1834— Pension of Joshua Turner of Pembroke.
16. V. Monday.

I called at the Pension Office of the War Department and made enquiries respecting the cases just above noted. Mr Edwards took minutes of them, and promised me answers— At the House after the reading of the Journal, the Report of the Committee on Invalid Pensions, was recommitted to be completed. Polk moved a suspension of the Rules which devote the Monday to the reception of Memorials and Petitions, to take up the Appropriation Bills at the third reading. He afterwards modified his motion to suspend the Rules at 1/2 past One
O’Clock, which was carried by a vote of more than two thirds— Polk moved a Call of the House upon which only 161 members answered to their names— After which further proceedings in the Call were dispensed with. M’Carty of Indiana, then made a Speech on Instructions from his Constituents in favour of the Bank of the United States. Then Wardwell commented upon certain Resolutions from New-York, and called up Philo C. Fuller, and Dudley Selden— Next followed Grennell upon a Memorial from his District, and then Burges upon the Resolutions of the Rhode-Island House of Representatives— He finished precisely at 1/2 past one, and at the motion of D. J. Pearce the subject was postponed till next Monday. The appropriation Bills were then taken up, and a debate ensued upon the Bill from the Senate for the continuation and repair of the Cumberland Road, which continued till near 7. O’Clock, when the House adjourned without coming to a decision. Polk’s motion to reduce the Appropriation, from 652130 dollars for repairs to 300000 was rejected by yeas and nays 92 to 91. The Speaker was called by Warren R. Davis to vote, but declined I moved an Amendment to Polks including his, but it was rejected— The Amendments were proposed by Sutherland and Philemon Dickerson, pending which the adjournment was carried— Mr Preston of the Senate was in the House, and said that the nomination of A. Stevenson, as Minister to Great Britain would be rejected by the Senate— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith visited us this Evening.

17. V. Tuesday.— An unquiet Night, and I was once called up— This morning I received from J. L. Edwards Commissioner of Pensions, a Letter in answer to my last enquiries, and I wrote three short Letters.— At the House, H. L. Pinckney moved a suspension of the Rule, to discharge from the Committee of the whole a Bill for laying a Tonnage duty on Spanish vessels. Cambreleng objected that it being a tax-bill, it must be first considered in Committee of the whole— Bell decided doubtingly that as a duty upon Spanish vessels, it was not a tax or charge upon the People, and not within the Rule. I requested Pinckney to withdraw his motion; as I should else be under the necessity of appealing from the decision of the Speaker. Pinckney withdrew his motion. S. Jones asked a suspension of the Rules, to offer sundry Resolutions of Regulation for the Post Office, but Connor, Chairman of the Post-Office Committee objected, and the House refused to suspend the Rules. The Cumberland Road Bill came up, and Gilmer of Georgia moved a reconsideration of the vote yesterday rejecting the reduction of the Sum of 652130 dollars for repairs to 300000 dollars and the whole debate was renewed for 5 hours when the previous question on reconsideration was taken and carried.— The reconsideration prevailed by a vote of 109. to 86.— And then the reduction to 300000 dollars— Next, M’Kennan’s motion to strike out the limitation in the third Section, and the fourth Section to surrender the road to the States, and to refuse all future appropriations followed. I moved the question should be separately taken on the first proposal to strike out the words, “for the entire completion of” (the repairs) this was lost by yeas and nays 92 to 114. Several amendments were proposed, and cutt off by the previous question on the Bill, moved by M’Kim and carried. I voted against the 3d. reading of the Bill. It passed by yeas and nays 127. to 72. and the Bill was immediately read the 3d. time and passed— The House adjourned after six. I walked home: part of the way with Mr Parker of New-Jersey— Mrs Goode’s daughter Mary had fits again.

18. V:30. Wednesday— Heavy Thunder Shower in the Night— Morning call at the Pension Office. I enquired of Mr Edwards, if he had not mistaken the name of Samuel Sampson for that of Levi Hayden— He had sent me a certificate of service for Sampson, without answering the enquiries concerning Hayden— He had destroyed his minutes, but promised to enquire further, and send me an answer.— At the House Watmough from the naval Committee renewed his motion for enquiry of the President, concerning the disaster at Toulon— The Resolution was received; but there
were not two thirds for consideration of it now— The Harbour Bill was taken up— I took a leisure moment to go into the Senate, where I found Mr Preston, urging a postponement of the general Appropriation Bill, till next Tuesday, to wait for a Bill from the House of Representatives, regulating the custody of the Public monies in the depository Banks. Webster admitted the force of Preston’s argument, but opposed his motion to postpone the Bill— Forsyth answered Preston, who replied— I was called back to the House, for the yeas and nays, upon the reduction of an appropriation for the improvement of red river, but was too late for my vote— The harbour and river Bill continued to be debated till past 7. O’Clock. The amendments adopted in Committee of the whole were chiefly confirmed, and other amendments were added— An Appropriation of 30,000 dollars for surveys was warmly debated, earnestly supported by me, and rejected by yeas and nays 89 to 100. This vote produced much excitement— Beaty moved to lay the Bill on the Table—rejected 66 to 123— The next and last Amendment reported from the Committee of the whole was for deep Creek, between Virginia and North-Carolina 29000 dollars, to which Beaty offered an amendment of 50000 for Cumberland river above Nashville— Then followed Motions, for the previous Question, for a Call of the House, to lay the Bill on the Table, and for reconsideration till the motion to adjourn succeeded— The rumour was generally circulated round the House, that Louis M’Lane, Secretary of State had resigned— Coll. Roger L. Gamble, member of the House from Georgia, requested me to write Lines in his daughter’s Album— Evening feeble.
19. V:15 Thursday.

Mr Choate called upon me this morning and introduced to me Mr Chadwick of Lynn and Mr Miller of Salem. I wrote a Sonnet to Miss Gamble in her Album, which I returned to her father— At the Meeting of the House the Speaker presented a communication from the President respecting the disaster at Toulon, by which two men were killed, and four wounded by guns fired from the United States Frigate, in a Salute on the French king’s birth day— There was a despatch from Mr Livingston to the Secretary of State, and Letters from Captain Ballard to Mr Livingston, and to the French Admiral, de Rigny.— The President recommends that provision should be made for the families of the sufferers— Referred to the Committee of Foreign Affairs— Other business of the routine was done, and Polk gave notice that he should to-morrow call up the Bill for regulating the public funds in the depository Banks— The unfinished business of yesterday was taken up;—the Harbour Bill— Mr Beaty withdrew his proposed amendment of an appropriation for Cumberland river, above Nashville— Mr Mercer moved as an amendment to the last Amendment of the Committee of the whole, an appropriation of 29000 dollars for surveys, instead of 30000 dollars rejected yesterday.— New debate of four hours, and the appropriation again rejected by a vote of 89 to 97.— Then Marshall of Kentucky moved to lay the Bill on the Table, which was carried 104 to 82. Campbell P. White moved to take up next the gold coin Bill; but the Fortification Bill was preferred— Polk moved to strike out 34000 dollars and insert 17000 dollars for Fort-Independence on Castle Island in Boston Harbour, which was carried— Then he moved to strike out 100000 dollars for George’s Island—Gorham, Edward Everett and Grennell defended the appropriation— Warren R. Davis assailed the whole Bill, followed by David Crockett, and Dunlap— Dudley Selden and Beardsley succeeded, and Polk replied— Felder proposed and Peyton moved to strike out the enacting clause of the Bill, upon which the debates grew warm till near 8 O’Clock, when the House adjourned. I walked home, part of the way with Amos Lane of Indiana, who was much offended with Polk for defeating the Harbour Bill— Evening abstinent.
20. V:15. Friday.

I had notified the members of the Committee of Manufactures to meet at ten O’Clock this morning; but the only members who attended were Mr Huntington and Mr Denny. I read the report on the Petition of Peter Bastress, which was approved, and as there was no Quorum, it was agreed that I should that the opinion of the other members of the Committee, and ask to be discharged from the further consideration of all the subjects referred to the Committee— In the House, Polk moved that the rules, devoting this day to private business should be suspended, for him to offer a Resolution that the Bill for regulating the depository Banks, should be taken out of the Committee of the whole and made the order of the day for this day at 12. O’Clock. This was carried by yeas and nays 114 to 53 Then Beardsley moved a reconsideration of the vote yesterday rejecting the appropriation of 29000 dollars for surveys, Lane having previously moved the reconsideration of the vote to lay the Harbour Bill on the Table. Both these motions were carried by yeas and nays—Lanes by 125 to 74 Beardsley’s by 111 to 76— The order of the day was postponed from 12 first to 1. and then to 3. O’Clock— The yeas and nays were taken seven times, upon reconsideration and motions to lay on the Table— Several Bills of a private nature were passed on. I made from the Committee of Manufactures an unfavourable report on the Petition of Peter Bastress, and moved the discharge of the Committee from further consideration of the Petition of James Jones—both were laid on the table— Archer from the Committee of foreign Affairs reported a joint Resolution, making provision for the families of the killed, and for the wounded by the unfortunate salute at Toulon; and as it contained an appropriation, it was at my Motion recommitted to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, with Instructions to report a Bill instead of the joint Resolution— At 3. O’Clock the Depository Bank Bill was taken up, and Polk made a Speech in support of it. Foster of Georgia opposed the Bill, on his individual doctrines and principles, and said he would but did not move an Amendment. Wilde opposed the Bill generally without proposing any amendment. Gordon of Virginia after a short Speech moved a substitute Bill, and Jones of Georgia another, both of which were ordered to be printed amidst much confusion and struggles for the floor between Jones and Coulter of Pennsylvania— Jones appealed from the decision of the Speaker in Coulter’s favour, but his appeal was not allowed— I called for the reading of Jones’s project but could not obtain it— Adjourned between 7 and 8. Mr Burges brought me his daughters Album with a request that I would write in it.

21. V:30. Saturday— Wasted the morning of the Summer Solstice— Just before going to the House I heard that intelligence had been received of the death of General La Fayette— At the Meeting of the House I moved a joint Resolution for the appointment of a Committee to consider and report what measures it may be proper for Congress to adopt, honorary to the Memory of General La Fayette. The Resolution was unanimously adopted, and a Committee of one member from each State, on the part of the House was appointed— The Senate immediately concurred, and ordered a Committee of 13 members on their part. Archer from the Committee of Foreign Affairs reported according to Instructions a Bill to provide for the Sufferers at Toulon—read twice and committed to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Polk moved a suspension of the Rules devoting the day to private business to take up the unfinished Bank deposit Bill of yesterday— The vote was 115 to 68. not two thirds. Campbell P. White moved to suspend the rules and take up the two Bills. N. 312 and 313. concerning the gold and silver currency.— Yeas and Nays 133 to 52. carried— Upon which C. P. White moved to strike out his whole Bill and to insert an entire new one— He made a Speech and was followed by Selden, Clowney and Gorham, with amendments. Jones of Georgia supported the new Bill, and the establishment of the proportion of 16 to 1, between gold and silver. H. Binney delivered a strong argument
against that proportion— Ewing of Indiana, then discoursed somewhat tediously, but amidst great disorder and confused insulting impatience of discourteous members, attempting to silence him by noisy interruption— John Y. Mason being in the Chair as Speaker, mildly remonstrated with the House, and Ewing was permitted to proceed— Gorham’s amendment was rejected, by yeas and nays 69 to 112— Selden’s by 52 to 129. Binney moved a 4th. Section, providing for annual assays of coins, which C P. White accepted as part of his new Bill— So amended the Bill passed to a third reading and then passed by a vote of 146. to 36. with the proportion of gold to silver at 16 for 1— Wilde had proposed an amendment fixing the proportion at 15.83 for 1. which was rejected— He voted against the Bill, as did Binney, and of the Massachusetts delegation Baylies, Everett, Gorham, Grennell, Lincoln and Reed— I voted for it, approving generally the principles of the Bill, and hoping that the proportion would be amended in the Senate.— The Bill for regulating the value of certain foreign gold coins, passed to be engrossed, and then was read the third time and passed without opposition—one or two other Bills were passed— There came one from the Senate granting double Pensions to the French Seamen wounded and to the relatives of the killed by the accident at Toulon. It passed through the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union; then to the third reading—was read the third time, when debate upon it arose, and at Beardsley’s motion it was postponed till next Monday— Two Messages were received from the President; one announcing the decease of La Fayette, and communicating the general Order to the army and navy, issued on the occasion— The other, communicating a memorial from the granddaughters of the Count de Rochambeau, claiming remuneration for his Services in the revolutionary War— It was referred to the Committee on foreign Affairs— The House adjourned, near 9. in the Evening.
22. V:30. Sunday.

I attended this morning at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the morning service for the fourth Sunday after Trinity, and Mr Butler of Troy New-York read the first part of the communion service, and preached from 1. Corinthians 1. part of v. 21—“the world by wisdom knew not God”— Mary, and her daughter Louisa were at Church with me— At 5. O’Clock afternoon I attended again at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the service, but I was the only respondent of part of it, and not twenty persons present at any part. Mr Hawley gave out two hymns to be sung, but there were no singers, and no performer on the Organ, and Mr Hawley’s exhortation substituted for a Sermon was not of five minutes duration. Between the two services there had been a long continued and very severe thunderstorm, in which the clouds in conflict seemed for a full half hour, to be suspended immediately over our heads— In the leisure of the day, I was reflecting upon the Resolutions and measures, which it might be proper to adopt on the occasion of the decease of La Fayette. I moved the appointment of the joint Committee, yesterday because I felt that my position required it specially of me, more than of any other member of Congress—but having done that my principle will be to let others do all the detail, and propose nothing myself. All may possibly thus go on smoothly. But if I should propose Resolutions written by myself, the instant they should be read in Committee, the Spirit of verbal criticism would be kindled in the joint Committee and there might be two days debate, without coming at last to a conclusion— I purposely left the number of the Committee on the part of the House in blank when I offered the Resolution yesterday— Five, and seven had been named; but one from each State was more acceptable to the House, and as it is, multitudes of members will be disappointed, in not being themselves upon the Committee— Mrs Frye was here this morning after the service at St. John’s Church was over.

23. V:30. Monday. The Committee on the part of the House to consider and report suitable tokens of respect to the memory of General La Fayette was announced, on the reading of the Journal— I was Chairman. The names of the members on the part of the Senate, 13. were afterwards communicated. I notified a meeting of the Committee at 1/2 past 9 to-morrow morning, at the chamber of the Committee of Commerce of the House. This was petition day: but Polk moved to suspend the rules after two O’Clock to take up his Bank-deposit Bill— I moved to substitute 5 O’Clock instead of 2.—rejected— Polk’s motion was divided—vote to suspend the rules carried—127 to 61— But not to take up the Bank deposit Bill—123 to 65— Gilmer, from the select Committee on the Bill from the Senate to settle and establish the Northern boundary of the State of Ohio, moved that the Committee be discharged from the further consideration of it, and that it be postponed till the next Session of Congress—the Bill at the motion of Leavitt of Ohio was laid on the table— The time till two O’Clock was wasted in violent altercation— Speeches between Burges and D. J. Pearce of Rhode-Island, upon Resolutions of the House of Representatives of that State, both touched upon the Hartford Convention. At two the Harbour Bill was taken up, and under a running fire for and against internal improvement till near 9 at night, with the Episode of a very heavy thundergust was carried by a final vote of 107 to 54— The appropriation of 29000 dollars for Surveys, voted down, upon my Speech the other day was now carried 92 to 82. All, by the change of Beardsley, and the New-York Van Buren members. Jones of Georgia, Felder of South-Carolina, and especially Wise of Virginia taunted them upon it, bitterly— Beatty of Kentucky, Ewing of Indiana and other western members flew the course, because they could not carry special favourite improvements of their own. The appropriation for surveys was the tug for life and death; the question for engrossment was carried by an increased majority, and the passage of the Bill by two to one— I saw Mr Webster twice in the House, and once in the Senate about the Meeting to-morrow of the La Fayette Committee, and W. S. Archer at my request drew up Resolutions to offer— I came home, pleased with the result of the day.
24. V. Tuesday.

At 1/2 past 9 this Morning the joint Committee of the two Houses of Congress on the honours to be paid to the Memory of General La Fayette, met in the room of the Committee of Commerce of the House of Representatives. 24 Members of the House and 13 of the Senate; all present except Joseph Duncan of Illinois. The Resolutions drawn yesterday by W. S. Archer were presented and Mr Clay offered one, embracing the substance of the three. Propositions were made for dressing in mourning the Halls of the Senate and House and the Chairs of the Vice President and Speaker for the remainder of the Session— Mr Calhoun offered a Resolution that I should be requested to deliver an Oration upon the Life and character of General La Fayette, before both Houses of Congress at their next Session— There was little discussion upon the Resolutions, which were unanimously adopted, and the two Chairmen, Mr Webster and myself were authorised to draw them up and report them— This was done with the aid of Mr Archer, and in the Evening I reported them to the House, where these were accepted, read three times and unanimously passed. At the House there was some discussion and much manoeuvering to take up the Bank deposit Bill, in preference to the fortification Bill— The Bank Bill prevailed, and after excellent senseless speeches from Coulter and Stewart of Pennsylvania, Jones of Georgia, and M’Vean of New-York, Miller of Pennsylvania moved the previous question, which was seconded and carried, and the Bill as reported by the Committee of Ways and means, passed the second and third reading, after a call of the House upon which only 175 members answered to their names, and 12 excuses received— The Bill passed by a vote of 112 to 90, about 25 members, being intentionally absent, to avoid voting— The Bill for pensioning the French
Sailors wounded, and the relatives of the two that were killed, by the Salute at Toulon was taken up and first recommitted to the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union—there entirely new-modelled, reported by Ward, chairman of the Committee of the whole, amended—then engrossed for a third reading, and finally read a third time and passed; after which the title was amended, to conform to the amendment of the Bill— M’Kinley of Alabama, made an objection upon Constitutional ground which I answered— The house refused him the yeas and nays upon the passage of the Bill— Adjourned about 1/2 past 6— The Senate this day rejected the nomination of Andrew Stevenson, as Minister to London, 23 to 22. of Roger B. Taney as Secretary of the Treasury 28 to 18 and confirmed Benjamin F Butler as Attorney General, without a division— Evening visit from John Connell.

25. V. Wednesday.— I received this morning a Letter from J. P. B. Storer, a Clergyman, at Walpole, Massachusetts, enclosing a claim for increase of pension, for a Soldier named Jeremiah Smith, the papers of which I immediately took, and delivered to the Secretary of War, Cass, who promised to examine the case, and send me an answer.— At the House, on the motion of Elisha Whittlesey, it was agreed for the remainder of the Session, to meet at 10. A.M. and to take a recess from 2 to 4. P.M. Clayton, from the Retrenchment Committee made a report in part which was read and laid on the table— Francis Thomas Chairman of the Bank investigating Committee, reported a Resolution that Friday next should be set apart for the consideration of the Report of that Committee; and that this consideration should be continued from day to day, until finally disposed of— Thomas as usual made a Speech, and then Watmough moved the question, whether Thomas’s motion should be considered by the House—considerable debate on this was allowed by the Speaker, after which the question was taken by yeas and nays, and carried for the consideration 97 to 65— I voted for the consideration, but before the debate could be got afloat the hour expired and the orders of the day were called— A question
